title: 105_hr4431
content: The "HIV Partner Protection Act" is cited as the short title. It amends the Public Health Service Act to include a section on partner notification for HIV health care services. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" amends the Public Health Service Act to require states to implement partner notification programs for individuals with HIV disease. This includes confidential reporting of positive test results and providing partners with information about potential exposure to the disease. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" mandates partner notification programs for individuals with HIV disease. Partners are informed of potential exposure without revealing the infected individuals' identities. Counseling, testing, and referrals for services are provided to both partners and infected individuals. Information on disease transmission and prevention measures is included in the counseling. Therapeutic measures for immune system deterioration and other prevention information are also offered. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" mandates partner notification programs for individuals with HIV disease. Referrals for services are provided to partners and infected individuals. Notifications are provided in person, with no penalties for non-cooperation. No penalties for errors in reporting. Failure to notify partners does not result in civil liability for health entities. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" requires partner notification programs for individuals with HIV disease. States must ensure that insurance laws prohibit discrimination against individuals who undergo testing for HIV. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" mandates partner notification programs for individuals with HIV disease. It defines an 'infected individual' as someone with HIV and includes various definitions for 'partner'. The Act also prohibits discrimination based on HIV testing results. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" requires partner notification programs for individuals with HIV disease. It includes definitions for 'infected individual' and 'partner', and prohibits discrimination based on HIV testing results. Delayed applicability for certain states is specified for fiscal years 2001 and beyond. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may provide grants to States to assist with the costs of implementing partner notification programs for HIV. $10,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated annually from 2000 to 2004 for this purpose.
